title: Linux File Permissions
question: Explain Linux file permissions. What does the permission 'rwxr-xr--' mean?
answer: Linux file permissions are divided into three groups: owner, group, and others. Each has read (r), write (w), and execute (x) permissions. 'rwxr-xr--' means: owner has full access (rwx), group can read and execute (r-x), others can only read (r--). Use chmod to modify permissions and chown to change ownership.
explanation: File permissions are fundamental to Linux security. They control who can read, write, or execute files. Understanding permissions is essential for troubleshooting access issues, setting up secure deployments, and managing shared resources in team environments.

codeExamples.label: View and modify permissions
codeExamples.code:
# View file permissions
ls -la myfile.sh
# Output: -rwxr-xr-- 1 devops team 1234 Dec 1 10:00 myfile.sh

# Make file executable
chmod +x script.sh

# Set specific permissions (owner: rwx, group: rx, others: r)
chmod 754 script.sh

# Recursive permission change
chmod -R 755 /var/www/html/

codeExamples.label: Change ownership
codeExamples.code:
# Change owner
chown newuser myfile.txt

# Change owner and group
chown newuser:newgroup myfile.txt

# Recursive ownership change
chown -R www-data:www-data /var/www/
